title: 125+ Funny English Words That Sound Totally Ridiculous

steps.title: Barnacle
steps.content: Barnacle A person or thing that clings tenaciously. Pronuciation: BAHR-nuh-kuhl Part of Speech: noun Example: “He’s a barnacle who won’t ever leave us alone.”

steps.title: Blubber
steps.content: Blubber A thick layer of fat. Pronuciation: BLUHB-er Part of Speech: noun Example: “There’s an awful lot of talk about whale blubber in Moby Dick .

steps.title: Bumbershoot
steps.content: Bumbershoot Another word for an umbrella. Pronuciation: BUM-bur-shoot Part of Speech: noun Example: “It’s supposed to rain today, so don’t forget your bumbershoot.”

steps.title: Bumfuzzle
steps.content: Bumfuzzle To be confused or perplexed. Pronuciation: BUM-fuz-el Part of Speech: verb Example: “That riddle has me bumfuzzled.”

steps.title: Cattywampus
steps.content: Cattywampus Another way to say catty-corner or diagonally. Pronuciation: kat-ee-WOHM-pus Part of Speech: adjective Example: “Your tie is all cattywampus. Let me fix it for you.”

steps.title: Diphthong
steps.content: Diphthong The sounds of 2 vowels joined together. Pronuciation: DIF-thawng Part of Speech: noun Example: “The ‘ou’ in ‘hound’ is a diphthong because you slide the sound of one vowel into the other as you say it”

steps.title: Dollop
steps.content: Dollop A lump, blob, or small quantity of something. Pronuciation: DOL-uhp Part of Speech: noun Example: “I’d like a dollop of whipped cream on top of my hot chocolate.”

steps.title: Flabbergasted
steps.content: Flabbergasted Shocked completely speechless. Pronuciation: FLAB-er-GAST-ed Part of Speech: adjective Example: “The end of that movie left me completely flabbergasted.”

steps.title: Flummoxed
steps.content: Flummoxed Utterly confused, bewildered, or puzzled. Pronuciation: FLUHM-uhkst Part of Speech: adjective Example: “This math problem has me flummoxed.”

steps.title: Fuddy-duddy
steps.content: Fuddy-duddy A person who is stuffy, old-fashioned, or conservative. Pronuciation: FUHD-ee-duhd-ee Part of Speech: noun Example: “He’s being such a fuddy-duddy about his daughter’s prom dress.”

steps.title: Fussbudget
steps.content: Fussbudget Someone who is overly concerned with details. Pronuciation: FUHS-buhj-it Part of Speech: noun Example: “He’s always been a fussbudget when it comes to his hair.”

steps.title: Gobbledygook
steps.content: Gobbledygook Something that’s meaningless or made into gibberish by overly technical terms. Pronuciation: GOB-uhl-dee-gook Part of Speech: noun Example: “Stop spouting gobbledygook. I can’t understand a word you’re saying.”

steps.title: Gobsmacked
steps.content: Gobsmacked To be shocked or flabbergasted. Pronuciation: GOB-smakt Part of Speech: adjective Example: “I was completely gobsmacked when they told me what happened.”

steps.title: Hobbledehoy
steps.content: Hobbledehoy An awkward, ungainly young person. Pronuciation: HOB-uhl-dee-hoi Part of Speech: noun Example: “I know she thinks I’m just a hobbledehoy after I knocked over that vase full of flowers.”

steps.title: Hodgepodge
steps.content: Hodgepodge A mixture or jumble of things. Pronuciation: HOJ-poj Part of Speech: noun Example: “My grandma made this blanket out of a hodgepodge of fabric scraps from worn-out shirts.”

steps.title: Hullabaloo
steps.content: Hullabaloo A commotion or mixture of loud noises that lasts a long time. Pronuciation: HUH-luh-buh–loo Part of Speech: noun Example: “What’s all the hullabaloo? It’s so loud, I can’t hear myself think.”

steps.title: Ragamuffin
steps.content: Ragamuffin A ragged, disreputable person or a child in dirty, ill-fitting clothing. Pronuciation: RAG-uh-muhf-in Part of Speech: noun Example: “Those frayed pants make you look like a ragamuffin.”

steps.title: Ramshackle
steps.content: Ramshackle Loosely held together or rickety. Pronuciation: RAM-shak-uhl Part of Speech: adjective Example: “I’m not going to live in that ramshackle apartment building.”

steps.title: Snollygoster
steps.content: Snollygoster An intelligent but unprincipled person who is often a politician. Pronuciation: SNOL-ee-gos-ter Part of Speech: noun Example: “She’s a snollygoster, but I think she’ll be our next state senator.”

steps.title: Whippersnapper
steps.content: Whippersnapper A young, overly confident person. Pronuciation: WIP-er-SNAP-er Part of Speech: noun Example: “That young whippersnapper thinks he knows everything.”

steps.title: Brouhaha
steps.content: Brouhaha An overreaction to an event that’s exciting or confusing. Pronuciation: BROO-hah-hah Part of Speech: noun Example: “Did you hear about the brouhaha after the football game last night?”

steps.title: Canoodle
steps.content: Canoodle Kissing and cuddling or interacting flirtatiously. Pronuciation: kuh-NOOD-l Part of Speech: verb Example: “The whole town saw you canoodling on the porch last night.”

steps.title: Cleek
steps.content: Cleek A large hook used to hang clothing or pots from the wall. Pronuciation: KLEEK Part of Speech: noun Example: “When you’re done washing that pot, hang it on the cleek over there.”

steps.title: Collop
steps.content: Collop A slice of meat. Pronuciation: KOL-uhp Part of Speech: noun Example: “I ate a collop of ham last night for dinner.”

steps.title: Dingus
steps.content: Dingus A foolish, stupid, or inept person. Pronuciation: DING-guhs Part of Speech: noun Example: “Don’t be such a dingus. Of course, I’m graduating this year.”

steps.title: Doozy
steps.content: Doozy Something that is extraordinary or outstanding. Pronuciation: DOO-zee Part of Speech: noun Example: “That lightning strike was a doozy. It sounded like it hit my chimney!”

steps.title: Futz
steps.content: Futz To pass the time in an idle fashion. Pronuciation: fuhts Part of Speech: verb Example: “All I did today was futz around.”

steps.title: Noob
steps.content: Noob Short for “newbie” meaning someone who is new. Pronuciation: NOOB Part of Speech: noun Example: “I’m such a noob, I don’t even know where the bathroom is.”

steps.title: Piffle
steps.content: Piffle Nonsense, or trivial, senseless conversation. Pronuciation: PIF-uhl Part of Speech: noun Example: “I can’t stand any piffle today. I’d rather go home and talk to myself.”

steps.title: Plonk
steps.content: Plonk Cheap or low-quality wine Pronuciation: PLONK Part of Speech: noun Example: “We drank two bottles of plonk before you got here.”

steps.title: Puggle
steps.content: Puggle A dog that’s a mix of a beagle and a pug. Pronuciation: PUHG-l Part of Speech: noun Example: “That is the cutest puppy I’ve ever seen! Is it a puggle?”

steps.title: Ratoon
steps.content: Ratoon A sprout or shoot coming off the end of a plant’s root. Pronuciation: ra-TOON Part of Speech: noun Example: “If you look closely, you can see the ratoon on my sugarcane plant.”

steps.title: Skirl
steps.content: Skirl To shriek or play the bagpipes. Pronuciation: skurl Part of Speech: verb Example: “Stop skirling! I can’t sleep with all that racket!”

steps.title: Smaze
steps.content: Smaze A mix of haze and smoke. Pronuciation: smeyz Part of Speech: noun Example: “The fires have caused really thick smaze today.”

steps.title: Swacked
steps.content: Swacked Drunk. Pronuciation: SWAKED Part of Speech: adjective Example: “After all of that booze, I’m completely swacked.”

steps.title: Titter
steps.content: Titter To giggle or laugh. Pronuciation: TIT-r Part of Speech: verb Example: “Are you going to titter after everything I say?”

steps.title: Whiffler
steps.content: Whiffler A person who frequently changes their opinions or interests. Pronuciation: HWIF-ler Part of Speech: noun Example: “Don’t be such a whiffler! Pick one hobby and stick with it.”

steps.title: Yitten
steps.content: Yitten Scared or frightened. Pronuciation: YIT-uhn Part of Speech: adjective Example: “After seeing a ghost in his living room, he’s yitten all the time.”

steps.title: Bawd
steps.content: Bawd A woman who maintains a brothel. Pronuciation: bawd Part of Speech: noun Example: “Elizabeth Cresswell was a successful bawd in London in the 1600s.”

steps.title: Bedswerver
steps.content: Bedswerver Someone who cheats on their partner. Pronuciation: BED-swurv-er Part of Speech: noun Example: “If she gets home early, she’s going to find out her husband is a bedswerver.”

steps.title: Bescumber
steps.content: Bescumber To spray excrement on something. Pronuciation: bee-SKUHM-berd Part of Speech: verb Example: “When the pipe broke, it bescumbered the entire bathroom.”

steps.title: Bunghole
steps.content: Bunghole A hole for emptying a cask or slang for anus. Pronuciation: BUHNG-hohl Part of Speech: noun Example: “Let me know when the wine stops flowing out of the cask’s bunghole.”

steps.title: Cuckold
steps.content: Cuckold A man with an unfaithful wife. Pronuciation: KUHK-uhld Part of Speech: noun Example: “Queen Guenivere made a cuckold of King Arthur when she had an affair with Lancelot.”

steps.title: Dollymop
steps.content: Dollymop A woman who dabbles in sex work or exchanges sex acts for pay. Pronuciation: DOL-ee-mop Part of Speech: noun Example: “People used to refer to an occasional sex worker as a dollymop, but we don’t use that word anymore.”

steps.title: Doxy
steps.content: Doxy An immoral, sexually promiscuous woman or sex worker. Pronuciation: DOK-see Part of Speech: noun Example: “In Oliver Twist , Nancy is often described as Bill Sikes’s doxy because she lives with him but they aren’t married.”

steps.title: Fleshmonger
steps.content: Fleshmonger A butcher, slave dealer, or someone who controls sex workers. Pronuciation: FLESH-mong-er Part of Speech: noun Example: “That movie was all about fleshmongers and sex workers.”

steps.title: Gal-sneaker
steps.content: Gal-sneaker A man who tries to seduce every woman he sees. Pronuciation: GAL-sneek-er Part of Speech: noun Example: “In the Victorian Era, they called pickup artists gal-sneakers.”

steps.title: Gingambobs
steps.content: Gingambobs Testicles. Pronuciation: GING-uhm-bobz Part of Speech: noun Example: “Don’t kick a man in his ginghambobs.”

steps.title: Hedge-born
steps.content: Hedge-born Of base birth or illegitimate, like bastard. Pronuciation: HEJ-bawrn Part of Speech: noun Example: “You have the look of a hedge-born toad!”

steps.title: Poxy
steps.content: Poxy Being currently or previously infected with syphilis. Pronuciation: POK-see Part of Speech: adjective Example: “Take that poxy blackguard out of here!”

steps.title: Ronyon
steps.content: Ronyon An old, mangy, scabby person. Pronuciation: RUHN-yuhn Part of Speech: noun Example: “You don’t want to date him. He’s a ronyon.”

steps.title: Sard
steps.content: Sard To have sex. Pronuciation: sahrd Part of Speech: verb Example: “It’s dishonorable to sard another man’s wife.”

steps.title: Skamelar
steps.content: Skamelar A parasite or a dirty freeloader. Pronuciation: SKA-mel-ahr Part of Speech: noun Example: “You get out of my house right now, skamelar!”

steps.title: Thingumbob
steps.content: Thingumbob Another word for a testicle or an insulting name to call someone when you can’t remember their real name. Pronuciation: THIN-gum-bob Part of Speech: noun Example: “You remember Thingumbob, the guy who tried to kick my dog every morning on his way to work.”

steps.title: Abecedarian
steps.content: Abecedarian Someone who is learning the alphabet. Pronuciation: AY-bee-see-DAHR-ee-uhn Part of Speech: noun Example: “Today, my kindergarten class became abecedarians.”

steps.title: Biblioklept
steps.content: Biblioklept A person who steals books. Pronuciation: BIB-lee-oh-klept Part of Speech: noun Example: “You can’t take her to the library with you. She’s a biblioklept.”

steps.title: Billingsgate
steps.content: Billingsgate Coarse or vulgar and abusive language. Pronuciation: BIL-ingz-geyt Part of Speech: noun Example: “I will not put up with any more of this billingsgate from you.”

steps.title: Collywobbles
steps.content: Collywobbles Intestinal cramps or a stomach ache. Pronuciation: KOL-ee-wob-uhlz Part of Speech: noun Example: “I shouldn’t eat too much cheese. It gives me collywobbles.”

steps.title: Conjubilant
steps.content: Conjubilant Shouting together with joy. Pronuciation: kon-JOOB-il-ant Part of Speech: adjective Example: “The crowd was conjubilant when the point guard sunk that 3-pointer.”

steps.title: Flibbertigibbet
steps.content: Flibbertigibbet A gossip or flighty person. Pronuciation: FLIB-er-tee-jib-it Part of Speech: noun Example: “If you don’t get more serious at work, people will think you’re just a flibbertigibbet.”

steps.title: Frippery
steps.content: Frippery Frills or finery in clothing that makes it showy or gaudy. Pronuciation: FRIP-uh-ree Part of Speech: noun Example: You don’t need all that frippery. You’re lovely without it.”

steps.title: Jackanapes
steps.content: Jackanapes An impertinent young person, usually a young man. Pronuciation: JAK-uh-neyps Part of Speech: noun Example: “Get back here, jackanapes! I’m not done talking to you.”

steps.title: Mollycoddle
steps.content: Mollycoddle A man or boy who is used to being coddled or spoiled. Pronuciation: MOL-ee-kod-l Part of Speech: noun Example: “He’s such a mollycoddle he hasn’t ever heard the word ‘no.’”

steps.title: Mugwump
steps.content: Mugwump A person who remains politically neutral or independent. Pronuciation: MUHG-wuhmp Part of Speech: noun Example: “It’s hard to stay a mugwump in an election like this.”

steps.title: Namby-pamby
steps.content: Namby-pamby Sentimental, pretentious, or lacking in character and decisiveness. Pronuciation: NAM-bee-PAM-bee Part of Speech: adjective Example: “Stop reading that namby-pamby poetry. It’s just pretty words with no meaning.”

steps.title: Octothorpe
steps.content: Octothorpe The hashtag # symbol. Pronuciation: OK-tuh-thawrp Part of Speech: noun Example: “You use a lot of octothorpes on your Insta posts.”

steps.title: Salopettes
steps.content: Salopettes High-waisted ski pants with shoulder straps. Pronuciation: sal-uh-PETS Part of Speech: noun Example: “Don’t forget to pack your salopettes for the ski trip.”

steps.title: Slumgullion
steps.content: Slumgullion A weak beverage or refuse from processing whale carcasses. Used to say something is gross. Pronuciation: sluhm-GUHL-yuhn Part of Speech: noun Example: “This slumgullion is inedible. Please take it away.”

steps.title: Snickersnee
steps.content: Snickersnee A sharp knife that’s used as a weapon. Pronuciation: SNIK-er-snee Part of Speech: noun Example: “Leave me alone, or I’ll jab you with my snickersnee!

steps.title: Taradiddle
steps.content: Taradiddle A small lie or fib. Pronuciation: tar-uh-DID-l Part of Speech: noun Example: “It was only a little taradiddle. I didn’t mean to mislead you.”

steps.title: Widdershins
steps.content: Widdershins A counter-clockwise direction. Pronuciation: WID-er-shins Part of Speech: adverb Example: “Carry the candle widdershins around the room.”

steps.title: Adorbs
steps.content: Adorbs Short for adorable. Pronuciation: uh-DORBS Part of Speech: adjective Example: “That skirt is adorbs on you.”

steps.title: Bazoo
steps.content: Bazoo A person’s mouth. Pronuciation: bah-ZOO Part of Speech: noun Example: “Every last piece of that cake when right into her bazoo.”

steps.title: Cockamamie
steps.content: Cockamamie Ridiculous, pointless, or nonsensical. Pronuciation: KOK-uh-mey-mee Part of Speech: adjective Example: “That boy is full of cockamamie schemes and wild ideas about his future.”

steps.title: Doohickey
steps.content: Doohickey A word to call something when you can’t remember its name. Pronuciation: DOO-hik-ee Part of Speech: noun Example: “Hand me that doohickey, would you?”

steps.title: Folderol
steps.content: Folderol Unnecessary words or actions. Pronuciation: FAHL-duh-rahl Part of Speech: noun Example: “Say something important instead of all this folderol.”

steps.title: Foppish
steps.content: Foppish Having excessively refined tastes and manners. Pronuciation: FOP-ish Part of Speech: adjective Example: “That cravat makes you look a little foppish.”

steps.title: Furphy
steps.content: Furphy A false rumor or story. Pronuciation: FUR-fee Part of Speech: noun Example: “I can’t believe you spread that furphy about me.”

steps.title: Gonzo
steps.content: Gonzo Bizarre or unconventional. Pronuciation: GAHN-zoh Part of Speech: adjective Example: “She’s a gonzo filmmaker who doesn’t always connect with the audience.”

steps.title: Hoodwink
steps.content: Hoodwink To deceive or trick someone. Pronuciation: HOOD-wingk Part of Speech: verb Example: “Don’t think you can hoodwink me into believing everything you say.”

steps.title: Hoosegow
steps.content: Hoosegow A jail or prison. Pronuciation: HOOS-gow Part of Speech: noun Example: “You steal that ring, and they’re going to send you to the hoosegow.”

steps.title: Kerfuffle
steps.content: Kerfuffle A dispute or disturbance caused by conflicting views. Pronuciation: ker-FUHF-uhl Part of Speech: noun Example: “The mayoral election caused a big kerfuffle last year.”

steps.title: Kibosh
steps.content: Kibosh Pronuciation: KEYE-bosh Part of Speech: verb Example: “I put the kibosh on that before they even got started.”

steps.title: Lickety-split
steps.content: Lickety-split Rapidly or at great speed. Pronuciation: LIK-i-tee-SPLIT Part of Speech: adverb Example: “You better get your coat on lickety-split. We were supposed to leave 5 minutes ago.”

steps.title: Nitwittery
steps.content: Nitwittery Stupidity. Pronuciation: nit-WIT-er-ee Part of Speech: noun Example: “This is a bunch of nitwittery, and I won’t be a part of it.”

steps.title: Schmooze
steps.content: Schmooze To chatter or talk idly to impress someone. Pronuciation: SHMOOZ Part of Speech: verb Example: “He schmoozed me through the entire party. It was so annoying.”

steps.title: Sozzled
steps.content: Sozzled Drunk Pronuciation: SOH-zuld Part of Speech: adjective Example: “If I have one more drink, I’ll be completely sozzled.”

steps.title: Whirligig
steps.content: Whirligig Something that whirls or revolves. It’s also used to describe a giddy or flighty person. Pronuciation: HWUR-li-gig Part of Speech: noun Example: That girl is a whirligig. I get tired just thinking about her.”

steps.title: Wishy-washy
steps.content: Wishy-washy Lacking in decisiveness or unable to make a decision. Pronuciation: WISH-ee-wosh-ee Part of Speech: adjective Example: “Stop being so wishy-washy about what you want for dinner.”

steps.title: Ackamarackus
steps.content: Ackamarackus A load of nonsense. Pronuciation: AK-uh-MAR-uh-RAK-us Part of Speech: noun Example: “That’s ackamararackus! You shouldn’t believe a word that girl says.”

steps.title: Arfarfan'arf
steps.content: Arfarfan'arf A slurred version of half-half-and-half, which refers to half-pints of ale and means “drunk.” Pronuciation: ARF-ARF-uhn-ARF Part of Speech: adjective Example: “He’s been drinking since 5 o’clock, so he’s thoroughly arfarfan’arf by now.”

steps.title: Balderdash
steps.content: Balderdash Something untrue or preposterous. Pronuciation: BAWL-der-dash Part of Speech: noun Example: “Every single word you’ve said today is balderdash!”

steps.title: Batty-fang
steps.content: Batty-fang To thrash or beat someone thoroughly. Pronuciation: BAT-ee-FANG Part of Speech: verb Example: “We batty-fanged him after he called my mother a toad.”

steps.title: Boondoggle
steps.content: Boondoggle A project that’s extravagant or useless. Pronuciation: BOON-dog-guhl Part of Speech: noun Example: “This whole event is such a boondoggle. I don’t know how we’ll afford it.”

steps.title: Chuckaboo
steps.content: Chuckaboo A close friend. Pronuciation: CHUHK-a-BOO Part of Speech: noun Example: “I grew up with him, so he’s my best chuckaboo.”

steps.title: Collie shangle
steps.content: Collie shangle An argument or quarrel with someone. Pronuciation: CAHL-lee-SHAN-gul Part of Speech: noun Example: “They got into a collie shangle over who got there first.”

steps.title: Firkytoodling
steps.content: Firkytoodling Kissing, cuddling, or making out. Pronuciation: FUR-kee-TOOD-ling Part of Speech: verb Example: “They’ve been firkytoodling in the corner all night.”

steps.title: Foozler
steps.content: Foozler A person who is clumsy or makes a mess. Pronuciation: FOO-zler Part of Speech: noun Example: “He’s such a foozler, I have to clean this place up every day.”

steps.title: Gigglemug
steps.content: Gigglemug A face that’s always smiling. Pronuciation: GIG-uhl-MUG Part of Speech: noun Example: “Sweetheart, you have such a gigglemug. You’re a ray of sunshine.”

steps.title: Kruger-spoof
steps.content: Kruger-spoof Another word for lying. Pronuciation: KRU-gehr-SPOOF Part of Speech: verb Example: “He got caught coming in late, but he kruger-spoofed his way back into her good graces.”

steps.title: Lollygag
steps.content: Lollygag To waste time or dawdle. Pronuciation: LOLL-ee-GAG Part of Speech: verb Example: “All you do is lollygag around all day.”

steps.title: Muffin-walloper
steps.content: Muffin-walloper An unmarried woman who spends her time gossiping. Pronuciation: MUHF-in-WOL-uhp-er Part of Speech: noun Example: “Betsy is destined to be a muffin-walloper if she doesn’t spend more time meeting new people.”

steps.title: Nanty-narking
steps.content: Nanty-narking Almost having too much fun. Pronuciation: NAN-tee-NARK-ing Part of Speech: verb Example: “Whenever we get together, it’s nanty-narking all day and night.”

steps.title: Scuttlebutt
steps.content: Scuttlebutt News or gossip. Pronuciation: SKUT-el-BUT Part of Speech: noun Example: “I saw her outside, so I caught up on all the scuttlebutt from this week.”

steps.title: Skilamalink
steps.content: Skilamalink A dishonest or underhanded person. Pronuciation: SKIL-a-mah-LINK Part of Speech: noun Example: “Don’t let him into your house. He’s a sticky-fingered skilamalink.”

steps.title: Tickety-boo
steps.content: Tickety-boo When something is in good condition. Pronuciation: TIK-et-ee-BOO Part of Speech: adjective Example: “My bedroom was a mess, but now it’s tickety-boo.”

steps.title: Whooperup
steps.content: Whooperup Someone who can’t sing but insists on doing it loudly. Pronuciation: WOOP-er-UHP Part of Speech: noun Example: “There’s a crowd of whooperups outside murdering “Bohemian Rhapsody.”

steps.title: Bacchanal
steps.content: Bacchanal To dance in honor of Bacchus, the Greek God of Wine. Pronuciation: bah-kuh-NAHL Part of Speech: verb Example: “Shall we dance now the Egyptian Bacchanals, And celebrate our drink?” – Antony and Cleopatra

steps.title: Bawcock
steps.content: Bawcock A fine fellow or good chap. Pronuciation: BAW-kok Part of Speech: noun Example: “I’fecks, Why, that’s my bawcock.” – The Winter’s Tale

steps.title: Cozen
steps.content: Cozen To deceive or use artful coaxing to convince someone to do something. [1] X Research source Pronuciation: KOH-zen Part of Speech: verb Example: “I will be hang’d, if some eternal villain, Some busy and insinuating rogue, Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office, Have not devised this slander; I’ll be hang’d else.” – Othello

steps.title: Foison
steps.content: Foison Abundance, plenty, or a profusion of something. [2] X Research source Pronuciation: FOI-zuhn Part of Speech: noun Example: “All things in common nature should produce Without sweat or endeavour: treason, felony, Sword, pike, knife, gun, or need of any engine, Would I not have; but nature should bring forth, Of its own kind, all foison, all abundance, To feed my innocent people.”

steps.title: Fustilarian
steps.content: Fustilarian A ponderous or clumsy person. Pronuciation: FUHST-il-AHR-ee-en Part of Speech: noun Example: “You scullion! You rampallian! You fustilarian! I’ll tickle your catastrophe!” – Henry IV, Part 2

steps.title: Gallimaufry
steps.content: Gallimaufry A mixture with a little bit of everything. Pronuciation: gal-uh-MAW-free Part of Speech: noun Example: “He wooes both high and low, both rich and poor, Both young and old, one with another, Ford; He loves the gallimaufry: Ford, perpend..” – The Merry Wives of Windsor

steps.title: Garboil
steps.content: Garboil A commotion, disturbance, or trouble. Pronuciation: GAHR-boil Part of Speech: noun Example: “She’s dead, my queen. Look here, at thy sovereign leisure read The garboils she awaked. At last, best, See when and where she died.” Antony and Cleopatra

steps.title: Kicky-wicky
steps.content: Kicky-wicky An affectionate term for a girlfriend or wife. Pronuciation: KIK-ee-WIK-ee Part of Speech: noun Example: “That hugs his kicky-wicky here at home.” – All’s Well That Ends Well

steps.title: Knotty-pated
steps.content: Knotty-pated Someone who is dull-witted or block-headed. Pronuciation: NOT-ee-PAYT-ed Part of Speech: adjective Example: “Thou clay-brained guts, thou knotty-pated fool, thou whoreson obscene greasy tallow-catch!” – Henry IV, Part I

steps.title: Lily-liver’d
steps.content: Lily-liver’d Someone who is weak and lacking courage. A coward. Pronuciation: LIL-ee-LIV-erd Part of Speech: adjective Example: “Go, prick thy face, and over-red thy fear, Thou lily-liver’d boy.” – Macbeth

steps.title: Miching
steps.content: Miching A kind of sneaking, lurking, or sulking. Pronuciation: MICH-ing Part of Speech: adverb Example: “Marry, this is miching mallecho. That means mischief.” – Hamlet

steps.title: Mobbled
steps.content: Mobbled To appear with your face veiled or covered up. [3] X Research source Pronuciation: MAH-bold Part of Speech: adjective Example: “‘But who, O who had seen the mobbled queen.” – Hamlet

steps.title: Noddle
steps.content: Noddle The back of the head. Pronuciation: NOD-l Part of Speech: noun Example: “Doubt not her care should be To comb your noddle with a three-legged stool.” – The Taming of the Shrew

steps.title: Pell-mell
steps.content: Pell-mell A chaotic mess, confused, disorderly. Pronuciation: PEL-MEL Part of Speech: adverb, adjective, or noun Example: “Advance your standards, and upon them, lords; Pell-mell, down with them!” – Love’s Labour’s Lost

steps.title: Sluggardized
steps.content: Sluggardized To turn someone into an idler or lazy person. [4] X Research source Pronuciation: SLUHG-ard-eyes Part of Speech: verb Example: “I rather would entreat thy company To see the wonders of the world abroad, Than, living dully sluggardized at home.” – The Two Gentlemen of Verona

steps.title: Sneap
steps.content: Sneap A snub, reproof, or rebuke. Pronuciation: SNEEP Part of Speech: noun Example: “My lord, I will not undergo this sneap without reply.” – Henry IV, Part II

steps.title: Starveling
steps.content: Starveling Someone or something that is starving. Pronuciation: STAHRV-ling Part of Speech: noun Example: “Away, you starvelling, you elf-skin, you dried neat’s-tongue, bull’s-pizzle, you stock-fish!” – Henry IV, Part I

steps.title: Urchin-snouted
steps.content: Urchin-snouted Having a nose like a goblin or a hedgehog. Pronuciation: UR-chin-SNOUT-ed Part of Speech: adjective Example: “But this foul, grim, and urchin-snouted boar.” Venus and Adonis
